rangees.data: Piezoelectric
Phenomenon where electricity is generated by the compression of a material (in ultrasonography, this material is a crystal)
Reflection (acoustic)
When a sound wave changes direction at the interface of two media, and returns to the first medium
Refraction (acoustic)
When a sound wave changes direction at the interface of two media (due to a difference in acoustic impedance) and continues (wholly or partially) into the second medium
Angle of incidence
Angle formed by the ultrasound beam and the surface of the tissue of interest
Spatial coherence of a beam

One can imagine that a beam with perfect spatial coherence would have all its constituent waves perfectly parallel to each other. Conversely, a beam with low spatial coherence is very heterogeneous in terms of the direction of its component waves
Scattering
When a surface exposed to waves is irregular in its relief and/or composition, the reflected/refracted waves are forced to deviate non-uniformly relative to each other
Timing, latency
Concept that refers to the time difference between wave emission and when this wave is captured by the transducer
Absorption
Phenomenon where the energy contained in sound waves is absorbed by the molecules of the medium, then converted into thermal energy (heat)
Attenuation (acoustic)
Gradual decrease in intensity of reflected sound waves due to absorption (mainly), refraction, and scattering
Interface
Surface formed by a common boundary between two tissues. For example, between a muscle and underlying bone, there is the muscle-bone interface.
Focal zone

Point where the beam diameter is at its minimum, where lateral resolution is optimal (due to increased convergence of the ultrasound beam on a restricted surface). This focal zone can be adjusted mechanically (by modifying ultrasound intensity and frequency, among others) or electronically
Beam (sound)
Set of sound waves emitted by a source and progressing in a given direction
Beam penetration
Degree to which a beam can traverse a large thickness of tissue while undergoing varying degrees of attenuation. Greater attenuation decreases beam intensity, which decreases its penetration.
Acoustic impedance

This concept can be imagined as the resistance that a medium imposes on the passage of sound waves. It is actually a characteristic property of a physical medium (e.g., a tissue like muscle) that refers to the amount of sound waves produced by a medium when subjected to vibration.
View / Plane

In the context of ultrasonography, pure orthogonal planes (sagittal, frontal, transverse) are not used as they would be with other imaging methods. Instead, we refer to nomenclature relative to the observed structures
Longitudinal view

A longitudinal view is used when the long axis of the probe is parallel to the long axis of the structure. For the arm, a longitudinal view refers to a probe whose long axis is parallel to the humeral diaphysis
Transverse view
This view classically designates (in ultrasound) a 90Â° rotation of the probe relative to a longitudinal view, thus in the 'short axis' of the observed structure.
Probe positioning convention
A positioning convention (see below) is used in most reference manuals, and on Physiographie, unless otherwise specified
Longitudinal view
On the screen, the left side refers to the cranial (proximal) aspect of the structure, while the right side logically refers to the caudal (distal) aspect
Transverse view
The left side of the image corresponds to the right side of the structure, while the right of the image corresponds to the left side
Echogenic
Term that refers to the ability of a structure to generate an echo, i.e., to reflect ultrasound. The more echogenic a structure is, the brighter it will appear on screen
Example: most structures of interest in a musculoskeletal context are echogenic (bone and soft tissues)
Hyperechoic
When a structure appears brighter (reflects more ultrasound) than another structure to which it is compared
Example: Tendons are normally hyperechoic compared to muscles
Hypoechoic
When a structure appears darker (thus reflects less ultrasound) than another structure to which it is compared
Example: Adipose tissue is hypoechoic compared to muscle tissue
Anechoic

That generates no echo (thus very dark or invisible on screen). This can be due to intrinsic tissue characteristics (e.g., strongly absorbing ultrasound) or due to more superficial structures that significantly reflect ultrasound
Example: Subcortical bone is anechoic, being underlying to cortical bone which appears strongly hyperechoic
Anisotropy
Property that certain tissues (like tendons and ligaments) have of seeing their apparent echogenicity modified according to the angle at which ultrasound reaches them

Depending on the case, a normally hypoechoic structure may appear hyperechoic and vice versa. This property can allow, for example, to distinguish a ligament from adipose tissue which is uniformly hypoechoic
In some cases, this property can lead to false observations if the probe angle is not precisely adjusted according to the anisotropic structure of interest
Artifact

This term used in several fields refers to any alteration of collected data that is caused by poor technique/manipulation or the equipment used to collect this data. See the Technique section to learn more about artifacts
Example in ultrasonography: with an anisotropic tissue, poor probe angulation could suggest erroneous echogenicity (risk of false positive or false negative)
Artifactual: that is the consequence of an artifact
False positive
When a result should be negative and it is interpreted, or perceived, as being positive
E.g.: An intact ligament that would be declared ruptured
False negative
In contrast to false positive, this is a falsely negative result (that should be positive)
E.g.: A ruptured ligament that would be declared intact
Resolution
In ultrasonography, this term can refer to two concepts (see below)
Lateral resolution
Ability to distinguish structures in a plane perpendicular to the ultrasound beam, thus at a common depth relative to each other
This is better with small transducers and with high frequencies
Axial resolution
Ability to distinguish superimposed structures at different depths
Signal strength
Refers to the intensity of reflected ultrasound that is captured by the transducer
Signal-to-noise ratio

This ratio serves to describe the quality of the signal perceived by a transducer by relating the signal from evaluated tissues with the 'background noise', considered harmful. Thus, a ratio greater than 1:1 corresponds to more signal than noise
This ratio can be affected (upward or downward) by several factors such as transducer size and quality and beam characteristics (e.g., frequency and amplitude)
Classic echotexture/structure of normal (healthy) tissues
Tendon: Fibrillar or fibrous structure, hyperechoic
Ligament: Striated structure, hyperechoic more compact than that of a tendon
Muscle: Relatively hypoechoic (compared to tendon). It is possible to observe muscle fascicles (hypoechoic) surrounded by their perimysium (hyperechoic)
Cortical bone (surface) or calcifications: Strongly hyperechoic, with a hypoechoic or anechoic background (subcortical bone)
Hyaline cartilage: Hypoechoic and uniform
Labrum: Hyperechoic
Adipose tissue: Hypoechoic and uniform
Peripheral nerve fibers: Fascicular appearance where the nerves themselves are hypoechoic and surrounded by hyperechoic connective tissue
Epidermis and dermis: Collectively hyperechoic
Hypodermis: Hypoechoic (adipose tissue) and hyperechoic (fibrous septum)
Depth
This parameter determines the desired depth of the ultrasound beam, which ideally should generate a focal zone encompassing the structures of interest
Gain
Allows adjustment of the overall brightness of structures appearing on screen
Frequency
Parameter that impacts the depth and resolution desired based on the structures to be observed (generally adjusted through depth)
Transducer / probe
Part of the ultrasonography device that functions to emit (produce) ultrasound, as well as receive reflected ultrasound
Static application
Refers to probe application on immobile structures. In contrast to dynamic application.
Dynamic application

This term is used when structures visualized via ultrasonography are simultaneously mobilized (actively or passively). In the shoulder region, this type of application can, among other things, be very useful in the context of an impingement syndrome or adhesive capsulitis
